Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Comparisons of conditional associations to navigate spatial location
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to use cues to navigate through the environment is a trait shared by mammals. This research focuses on spatial cognition procedures in two mammal species (rats and humans) to explore similarities and differences in learning and memory. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Tohru Taniuchi, a noted expert in comparative psychology at Kanazwa University in Japan. A major aim of the project is to explore conditional relations by setting up experiments on either a two-dimensional touchscreen monitor (humans), three-dimensional search task (humans), or an iPad equipped apparatus (rats). Making species comparisons by exploring conditional relations during search tasks will further elucidate the true psychological mechanism backing our species extraordinary ability to navigate through space.

Aristotle pondered the concept of an association, contending that objects close together in space tend to be associated together, however, considerably less is known about how spatial information is encoded within a conditional relation. This project will train rats and humans that the spatial location of a hidden goal, in relation to the landmark, is entirely conditional on the conditional cue paired with it. Transfer tests will pit pre-trained conditional cues with landmarks differing from training, to assess the general excitatory, and spatial properties of the conditional cue. The results will be discussed within the backdrop of current configural and hierarchical accounts of conditional relations. The findings of this project will be incorporated into educational research examining why children have particular problems solving problems in geometry and trigonometry: two subfields of mathematics that require both conditional and spatial reasoning. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mobile organisms navigate and encode their position in space through the use of landmarks. The informational (spatial) value of any one landmark is often conditional upon a number of factors such as the positional heading of the organism or the visual background information surrounding the landmark. One way to examine the mechanisms that back our ever-evolving representations of space is to conduct landmark search tasks in which the spatial relation of the landmark to the goal (left vs. right) is conditional on the presentation of a unique background. These experiments have targeted both animal subjects (e.g., Leising, Wolf, & Ruprecht, 2015), and human participants (Ruprecht, Quintana, Wolf, & Leising, 2014), but so far, have been conducted in mostly two dimensions (touchscreens). 

What remained to be investigated was the nature of landmark anchored spatial relations that fall under conditional control during three dimensional search tasks. In collaboration with Dr. Tohru Tanicuchi of Kanazwa University, we explored the role of spatial relations during conditional learning using both animal and human research participants.  We made two specific predictions: a) The Conditional Cue, called X, (e.g., the view of a downtown skyline who have when approaching a target) would be better at conveying directional information (e.g., head north, south, east, or west, to approach the target. b) the landmark, called A, would be more efficient at conveying distance information (e.g., head far vs. near the landmark). To experimentally assess each cues individual strength, two groups were trained on an XA+, A- contingency, meaning the landmarks general and spatial relevance depended on whether X visually preceded it. To examine the functionality of each cue, the groups differed in that for Group 1, X signaled direction information and in Group 2, X signaled distance information. That meant for Group 1, the landmark conveyed distance (far vs. near) and for Group 2, the landmark conveyed direction (east vs. west). Based on previous open-field observations (e.g.,Knierim & Hamilton, 2011), we hypothesized that Group 1 would learn the task more efficiently and perform more accurately than Group 2 (see Figure 1).

Across the life of the project, three experiments were run on vastly different platforms (or species). Experiment 1 tested Japanese and American undergraduate’s use of conditional cues and landmarks that conveyed varying spatial information (distance or direction, respectively) in two dimensions conducted on a standard computer monitor (see Figure 1). The hypothesis that Group 1 (Conditional-Direction; Landmark-Distance) would acquire the spatial discrimination faster than Group 2 (Conditional-Distance; Landmark-Direction) was not supported in two dimensions. Experiment 2 tested undergraduate’s use of conditional cues and landmarks in a small scale three- dimensional task that involved orientating to a room from a single start zone, and then navigating to the target location (see Figure 2). Again, the hypothesis that Group 1 would acquire the FP spatial discrimination faster than Group 2 was largely disconfirmed. It appeared female participants arrived to the target quicker than males (see Figure 4), however, the time it takes to arrive to the target is a performance variable, making it difficult to claim that females were “better” than males at learning the task. Finally, Experiment 3 tested rat’s search behavior in an open field (see Figure 3) when a conditional cue or landmark conveyed differing sources of spatial information.
